questions.text: Structure not removed in radical neck dissection:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sublingual gland Radical neck dissection spares Sublingual gland.

Highyeild:

Radical neck dissection involves the removal of: All ipsilateral cervical lymph node groups extending from the inferior border of the mandible to the clavicle and from the lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle, hyoid bone, and contralateral anterior belly of the digastric muscle medially to the anterior border of the trapezius muscle laterally. Radical Neck Dissection Level I Level II Level III Level IV Level V Other Structures excised Sternocleidomastoid muscle Internal Jugular vein Spinal Accessory nerve Submandibular salivary gland

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- SCM muscle is removed in radical neck dissection. OPTION C- Spinal Accessory nerve is also removed in radical neck dissection. OPTION D- Level 1-5 lymph nodes are also removed in radical neck dissection.

Extraedge:

Contraindications to radical neck dissection include: Untreatable primary cancer. Distant metastases. Inoperable neck nodes when they are fixed to important structures. Medical illness which makes the patient unfit for major surgery

questions.text: A patient underwent lateral skull base surgery few months back and has presented with complaints of recurrent aspirations. There is no change in voice of the patient. Which of the following nerve is most likely injured during this surgery?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SLN U/L SLN palsy: MC due to neck surgery. Leads to loss of pitch and aspiration. Treated with conservative management. So the above patient has superior laryngeal nerve injury.

Highyeild:

In SLN injury only cricothyroid muscle is involved which is used in high pitch vocalization, normal speech is not affected. It also provide sensory supply to mucosa above vocal cords, so it’s lesion would lead to increased chances of aspiration.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Vagal injury means both RLN and SLN are affected, so ruled out. OPTION B- Glossopharyngeal nerve don’t have sensory or motor supply to larynx. OPTION D - In RLN palsy there will be hoarseness of voice.

Extraedge:

U/L RLN palsy: MC affected is left RLN (because of longer course). But in neck surgery most commonly injured nerve is right RLN due to superficial course. Leads to hoarseness due to paramedian position of vocal cord. Treated with conservative management.

questions.text: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome is associated with all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sensorineural Hearing Loss In Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome sensorineural hearing loss will not be seen. Instead it causes apparent conductive hearing loss.

Highyeild:

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome is a set of hearing and balance symptoms, related to a rare medical condition of the inner ear, known as superior canal dehiscence. The symptoms are caused by a thinning or complete absence of the part of the temporal bone overlying the superior semicircular canal of the vestibular system. Low-frequency conductive hearing loss is present in many patients with SCDS and is explained by the dehiscence acting as a "third window." Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome/3rd window syndrome: disease of inner ear leading to Conductive Hearing Loss. Superior semicircular canal dehiscence creates a 3rd window –when oval window goes in some part of energy is lost via 3rd window and leads to conductive hearing loss. Clinical Features: Vertigo, oscillopsia, autophony, Tullio’s phenomenon, fullness/pressure in the ear. Patient’s bone conduction is super normal.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Gaze dependent nystagmus may be seen in Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome. OPTION B- Positive Tullio’s phenomenon may also be seen in Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome. OPTION C- Positive fistula test (Hennebert sign) is also seen in Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome.

questions.text: A young man with history of ear infection presents with a smooth erythematous swelling on mastoid process. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute mastoiditis Question itself mentions that there is ear infection and smooth erythematous swelling on mastoid process. This is known as ironed out mastoid. This is seen in case of acute mastoiditis.

Highyeild:

ACUTE MASTOIDITIS SYMPTOMS Pain behind the ear Fever Ear discharge SIGNS Mastoid tenderness Ear discharge Sagging of posterosuperior meatal wall. Perforation of tympanic membrane. Swelling over the mastoid

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- In case of Furunculosis: Patient will have ear pain, EAC swelling and pinna is pushed laterally. OPTION C- In Fibrous dysplasia, bone is replaced by fibrous tissue; mostly involves maxillary but sometimes the ethmoid and frontal sinuses. Patient seeks advice for disfigurement of the face, nasal obstruction and displacement of the eye. Treatment is surgical resculpturing of the involved bone to achieve a good cosmetic and functional result. OPTION D- In facial palsy deviation of angle of mouth may be seen.
